sentences: Kristin "Krista" Siegfrids (born 4 December 1985) is a Finnish singer and television presenter.
section: N/A

sentences: She represented Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 with her entry "Marry Me".
section: N/A

sentences: Siegfrids' debut album, named Ding Dong!, was released in May 2013.

sentences: As a television presenter, she hosted Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu from 2016 to 2020.

sentences: Siegfrids was born into the Swedish-speaking minority in Kaskinen in western Finland.

sentences: Her mother tongue is Swedish, though Siegfrids also speaks fluent Finnish and English.

sentences: Siegfrids started her career with her band Daisy Jack in 2009.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2012: Daisy Jack and The Voice ===

sentences: Their first single was Perfect Crime, released in October 2011.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2012: Daisy Jack and The Voice ===

sentences: She achieved her first musical role in the musical, Play Me (2009-2010) at the Swedish Theatre in Helsinki.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2012: Daisy Jack and The Voice ===

sentences: Her next major career step was to be cast in the rock musical Muskettisoturit, (The Three Musketeers, 2011) at the Finnish Peacock Theatre in Helsinki.
section: == Career == | === 2009–2012: Daisy Jack and The Voice ===

sentences: Siegfrids participated in the first season of The Voice of Finland (2011–2012) but was dropped in the semifinals.

== Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: Siegfrids participated in Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2013 for the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 with the song "Marry Me".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: The 27-year-old Siegfrids won the contest held at Barona Areena by attaining the maximum vote of both the public and judges.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: She was elected to represent Finland in Malmö.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: During her performance, she shared a kiss with one of the female dancers on stage.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: According to Siegfrids, the act was a part of the show and urged Finland to legalize same-sex marriage.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: On 16 May, her entry made it to the final of the Eurovision on 18 May.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: However, in the finals it finished 24th out of the 26 countries with a total of 13 points.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: According to the Executive Supervisor of the Eurovision Song Contest, Jon Ola Sand, Turkey had announced in November that it would not participate in the Eurovision Song Contest.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: Though the channel promised to show the contest, Turkey's TRT cancelled showing the semifinal and the finals over what LGBT activists alleged was fears of Siegfrids' promised lesbian kiss.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: When China broadcast the Eurovision Song Contest in October 2013, officials aired Siegfrid's performance but removed the kiss as a result of the television censorship in China and violation of Chinese ethics, sparking outrage among Eurovision fans in the country.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: Siegfrids' debut album, Ding Dong!, was released on 10 May 2013.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: Later, it was announced that she would be a guest on Big Brother's Bit on the Side, a spin-off of the British version of Big Brother.
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: She represented Finland in the Sopot Festival in concert "Top of the Top" on 23 August 2013 with her entry "Marry Me".
section: == Career == | === 2013–2015: Eurovision Song Contest and Ding Dong! ===

sentences: Siegfrieds was the spokesperson for Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015 in Vienna and gave the top mark of twelve points to Sweden's Måns Zelmerlöw and his song "Heroes", which went on to win the contest.

== Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: Siegfrids has presented Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu, the Finnish national selection show for Eurovision since 2016.
section: == Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: At the same time she participated in the Swedish national selection show Melodifestivalen 2016 with the song "Faller", but did not advance from second semifinal after placing fifth.
section: == Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: In September, she signed a contract with Universal Music Sweden and Stereoscope Scandinavia.
section: == Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: She participated in third semifinal Melodifestivalen 2017 with the song "Snurra min jord", but did not advance after placing seventh.
section: == Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: For the Eurovision Song Contest 2021, she hosted Krista Calling, a backstage series broadcast on Eurovision's official YouTube channel.
section: == Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: Siegfrids participated in Tanssii tähtien kanssa, the finnish version of Dancing with the stars in the fall of 2021.
section: == Career == | === 2016–present: Melodifestivalen and Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu ===

sentences: She finished the competition in second place.
